Principle.$description: Information and user interface components must be presentable to users in ways they can perceive.

Category.$description: Provide text alternatives for any non-text content so that it can be changed into other forms people need, such as large print, braille, speech, symbols or simpler language.

Success_Criterion.$description: All non-text content that is presented to the user has a text alternative that serves the equivalent purpose, except for the situations listed below. Level A. (https://www.w3.org/TR/WCAG22/#non-text-content)

Instructions.$value: All non-text content that is presented to the user has a text alternative that serves the equivalent purpose, except for the situations listed below.

Case_1.$value: Controls, Input - If non-text content is a control or accepts user input, then it has a name that describes its purpose. (Refer to Guideline 4.1 for additional requirements for controls and content that accepts user input.)
Case_1.$description: Controls, Input - If non-text content is a control or accepts user input, then it has a name that describes its purpose. (Refer to Guideline 4.1 for additional requirements for controls and content that accepts user input.)

Case_2.$value: Time-based Media - If non-text content is time-based media, then text alternatives at least provide descriptive identification of the non-text content. (Refer to Guideline 1.2 for additional requirements for media.)
Case_2.$description: Time-based Media - If non-text content is time-based media, then text alternatives at least provide descriptive identification of the non-text content. (Refer to Guideline 1.2 for additional requirements for media.)

Case_3.$value: Test - If non-text content is a test or exercise that would be invalid if presented in text, then text alternatives at least provide descriptive identification of the non-text content.
Case_3.$description: Test - If non-text content is a test or exercise that would be invalid if presented in text, then text alternatives at least provide descriptive identification of the non-text content.

Case_4.$value: Sensory - If non-text content is primarily intended to create a specific sensory experience, then text alternatives at least provide descriptive identification of the non-text content.
Case_4.$description: Sensory - If non-text content is primarily intended to create a specific sensory experience, then text alternatives at least provide descriptive identification of the non-text content.

Case_5.$value: CAPTCHA - If the purpose of non-text content is to confirm that content is being accessed by a person rather than a computer, then text alternatives that identify and describe the purpose of the non-text content are provided, and alternative forms of CAPTCHA using output modes for different types of sensory perception are provided to accommodate different disabilities.
Case_5.$description: CAPTCHA - If the purpose of non-text content is to confirm that content is being accessed by a person rather than a computer, then text alternatives that identify and describe the purpose of the non-text content are provided, and alternative forms of CAPTCHA using output modes for different types of sensory perception are provided to accommodate different disabilities.

Case_6.$value: Decoration, Formatting, Invisible - If non-text content is pure decoration, is used only for visual formatting, or is not presented to users, then it is implemented in a way that it can be ignored by assistive technology.
Case_6.$description: Decoration, Formatting, Invisible - If non-text content is pure decoration, is used only for visual formatting, or is not presented to users, then it is implemented in a way that it can be ignored by assistive technology.

Link.$description: 1.1.1 (A) - All non-text content that is presented to the user has a text alternative that serves the equivalent purpose, except for the situations listed below.

Category.$description: Provide alternatives for time-based media.

Success_Criterion.$description: For prerecorded audio-only and prerecorded video-only media, the following are true, except when the audio or video is a media alternative for text and is clearly labeled as such. Level A. (https://www.w3.org/TR/WCAG22/#audio-only-and-video-only-prerecorded)

Instructions.$value: For prerecorded audio-only and prerecorded video-only media, the following are true, except when the audio or video is a media alternative for text and is clearly labeled as such.

Case_1.$value: Prerecorded Audio-only - An alternative for time-based media is provided that presents equivalent information for prerecorded audio-only content.
Case_1.$description: Prerecorded Audio-only - An alternative for time-based media is provided that presents equivalent information for prerecorded audio-only content.

Case_2.$value: Prerecorded Video-only - Either an alternative for time-based media or an audio track is provided that presents equivalent information for prerecorded video-only content.
Case_2.$description: Prerecorded Video-only - Either an alternative for time-based media or an audio track is provided that presents equivalent information for prerecorded video-only content.

Level A. (https://www.w3.org/TR/WCAG22/#audio-control)

Instructions.$value: If any audio on a Web page plays automatically for more than 3 seconds, either a mechanism is available to pause or stop the audio, or a mechanism is available to control audio volume independently from the overall system volume level.

Note_1.$value: Since any content that does not meet this success criterion can interfere with a user's ability to use the whole page, all content on the Web page (whether or not it is used to meet other success criteria) must meet this success criterion. Principle.$description: User interface components and navigation must be operable.

Category.$description: Make all functionality available from a keyboard.

Success_Criterion.$description: All functionality of the content is operable through a keyboard interface without requiring specific timings for individual keystrokes, except where the underlying function requires input that depends on the path of the user's movement and not just the endpoints. Level A. (https://www.w3.org/TR/WCAG22/#keyboard)

Instructions.$value: All functionality of the content is operable through a keyboard interface without requiring specific timings for individual keystrokes, except where the underlying function requires input that depends on the path of the user's movement and not just the endpoints.

Note_1.$value: This exception relates to the underlying function, not the input technique. For example, if using handwriting to enter text, the input technique (handwriting) requires path-dependent input but the underlying function (text input) does not.
Note_1.$description: Additional information or clarification about the guideline.

Note_2.$value: This does not forbid and should not discourage providing mouse input or other input methods in addition to keyboard operation.
Note_2.$description: Additional information or clarification about the guideline.

Link.$description: 2.1.1 (A) - All functionality of the content is operable through a keyboard interface without requiring specific timings for individual keystrokes, except where the underlying function requires input that depends on the path of the user's movement and not just the endpoints.

Instructions.$value: If a keyboard shortcut is implemented in content using only letter (including upper- and lower-case letters), punctuation, number, or symbol characters, then at least one of the following is true:

Case_1.$description: Turn off - A mechanism is available to turn the shortcut off;

Case_2.$description: Remap - A mechanism is available to remap the shortcut to use one or more non-printable keyboard characters (e.g. Ctrl, Alt, etc);

Case_3.$value: Active only on focus - The keyboard shortcut for a user interface component is only active when that component has focus.
Case_3.$description: Active only on focus - The keyboard shortcut for a user interface component is only active when that component has focus.

Principle.$description: User interface components and navigation must be operable.

Category.$description: Provide users enough time to read and use content.

Success_Criterion.$description: For each time limit that is set by the content, at least one of the following is true: Level A. (https://www.w3.org/TR/WCAG22/#timing-adjustable)

Instructions.$value: For each time limit that is set by the content, at least one of the following is true:

Case_1.$value: Turn off - The user is allowed to turn off the time limit before encountering it; or
Case_1.$description: Turn off - The user is allowed to turn off the time limit before encountering it; or

Case_2.$value: Adjust - The user is allowed to adjust the time limit before encountering it over a wide range that is at least ten times the length of the default setting; or
Case_2.$description: Adjust - The user is allowed to adjust the time limit before encountering it over a wide range that is at least ten times the length of the default setting; or

Case_3.$value: Extend - The user is warned before time expires and given at least 20 seconds to extend the time limit with a simple action (for example, 'press the space bar'), and the user is allowed to extend the time limit at least ten times; or
Case_3.$description: Extend - The user is warned before time expires and given at least 20 seconds to extend the time limit with a simple action (for example, 'press the space bar'), and the user is allowed to extend the time limit at least ten times; or

Case_4.$value: Real-time Exception - The time limit is a required part of a real-time event (for example, an auction), and no alternative to the time limit is possible; or
Case_4.$description: Real-time Exception - The time limit is a required part of a real-time event (for example, an auction), and no alternative to the time limit is possible; or

Case_5.$value: Essential Exception - The time limit is essential and extending it would invalidate the activity; or
Case_5.$description: Essential Exception - The time limit is essential and extending it would invalidate the activity; or

Case_6.$value: 20 Hour Exception - The time limit is longer than 20 hours.
Case_6.$description: 20 Hour Exception - The time limit is longer than 20 hours.

Note_1.$value: This success criterion helps ensure that users can complete tasks without unexpected changes in content or context that are a result of a time limit. This success criterion should be considered in conjunction with Success Criterion 3.2.1 (https://www.w3.org/TR/WCAG22/#on-focus), which puts limits on changes of content or context as a result of user action.
Note_1.$description: Additional information or clarification about the guideline.

Success_Criterion.$description: For moving, blinking, scrolling, or auto-updating information, all of the following are true: Level A. (https://www.w3.org/TR/WCAG22/#pause-stop-hide)

Instructions.$value: For moving, blinking, scrolling, or auto-updating information, all of the following are true:

Case_1.$value: Moving, blinking, scrolling - For any moving, blinking or scrolling information that (1) starts automatically, (2) lasts more than five seconds, and (3) is presented in parallel with other content, there is a mechanism for the user to pause, stop, or hide it unless the movement, blinking, or scrolling is part of an activity where it is essential; and
Case_1.$description: Moving, blinking, scrolling - For any moving, blinking or scrolling information that (1) starts automatically, (2) lasts more than five seconds, and (3) is presented in parallel with other content, there is a mechanism for the user to pause, stop, or hide it unless the movement, blinking, or scrolling is part of an activity where it is essential; and

Case_2.$value: Auto-updating - For any auto-updating information that (1) starts automatically and (2) is presented in parallel with other content, there is a mechanism for the user to pause, stop, or hide it or to control the frequency of the update unless the auto-updating is part of an activity where it is essential.
Case_2.$description: Auto-updating - For any auto-updating information that (1) starts automatically and (2) is presented in parallel with other content, there is a mechanism for the user to pause, stop, or hide it or to control the frequency of the update unless the auto-updating is part of an activity where it is essential.

Note_1.$value: For requirements related to flickering or flashing content, refer to Guideline 2.3. (https://www.w3.org/TR/WCAG22/#seizures-and-physical-reactions)
Note_1.$description: Additional information or clarification about the guideline.

Note_2.$value: Since any content that does not meet this success criterion can interfere with a user's ability to use the whole page, all content on the Web page (whether it is used to meet other success criteria or not) must meet this success criterion. See Conformance Requirement 5: Non-Interference (https://www.w3.org/TR/WCAG22/#cc5)
Note_2.$description: Additional information or clarification about the guideline.

Note_3.$value: Content that is updated periodically by software or that is streamed to the user agent is not required to preserve or present information that is generated or received between the initiation of the pause and resuming presentation, as this may not be technically possible, and in many situations could be misleading to do so.
Note_3.$description: Additional information or clarification about the guideline.

Note_4.$value: An animation that occurs as part of a preload phase or similar situation can be considered essential if interaction cannot occur during that phase for all users and if not indicating progress could confuse users or cause them to think that content was frozen or broken.
Note_4.$description: Additional information or clarification about the guideline.

Case_2.$value: Abort or Undo - Completion of the function is on the up-event, and a mechanism is available to abort the function before completion or to undo the function after completion;
Case_2.$description: Abort or Undo - Completion of the function is on the up-event, and a mechanism is available to abort the function before completion or to undo the function after completion;

Case_3.$value: Up Reversal - The up-event reverses any outcome of the preceding down-event;
Case_3.$description: Up Reversal - The up-event reverses any outcome of the preceding down-event;

Case_4.$value: Essential - Completing the function on the down-event is essential.
Case_4.$description: Essential - Completing the function on the down-event is essential.

Case_2.$description: Human contact mechanism; - undefined

Case_4.$value: A fully automated contact mechanism. - undefined

Note_1.$value: A fully automated contact mechanism.

Note_2.$value: For this Success Criterion, the same order relative to other page content can be thought of as how the content is ordered when the page is serialized. The user can initiate a change, such as changing the pages zoom or orientation, which may trigger a different page variation. This criterion is concerned with relative order across pages displayed in the same page variation (e.g., same zoom level and orientation).

Case_1.$value: Dismissable - A mechanism is available to dismiss the additional content without moving pointer hover or keyboard focus, unless the additional content communicates an input error or does not obscure or replace other content;
Case_1.$description: Dismissable - A mechanism is available to dismiss the additional content without moving pointer hover or keyboard focus, unless the additional content communicates an input error or does not obscure or replace other content;

Case_2.$value: Hoverable - If pointer hover can trigger the additional content, then the pointer can be moved over the additional content without the additional content disappearing;
Case_2.$description: Hoverable - If pointer hover can trigger the additional content, then the pointer can be moved over the additional content without the additional content disappearing;

Case_3.$value: Persistent - The additional content remains visible until the hover or focus trigger is removed, the user dismisses it, or its information is no longer valid.

Case_4.$description: Exception: The visual presentation of the additional content is controlled by the user agent and is not modified by the author. - undefined

Instructions.$value: A cognitive function test (such as remembering a password or solving a puzzle) is not required for any step in an authentication process unless that step provides at least one of the following:

Case_1.$value: Alternative - Another authentication method that does not rely on a cognitive function test.
Case_1.$description: Alternative - Another authentication method that does not rely on a cognitive function test.

Case_2.$value: Mechanism - A mechanism is available to assist the user in completing the cognitive function test.
Case_2.$description: Mechanism - A mechanism is available to assist the user in completing the cognitive function test.

Case_3.$value: Object Recognition - The cognitive function test is to recognize objects.
Case_3.$description: Object Recognition - The cognitive function test is to recognize objects.

Case_4.$value: Personal Content - The cognitive function test is to identify non-text content the user provided to the Web site.
Case_4.$description: Personal Content - The cognitive function test is to identify non-text content the user provided to the Web site.

Note_1.$value: Object recognition and Personal content may be represented by images, video, or audio.
Note_1.$description: Additional information or clarification about the guideline.

Note_2.$value:
Examples of mechanisms that satisfy this criterion include:
  1. support for password entry by password managers to reduce memory need, and
  2. copy and paste to reduce the cognitive burden of re-typing.
Note_2.$description: Additional information or clarification about the guideline.

Success_Criterion.$description: A cognitive function test (such as remembering a password or solving a puzzle) is not required for any step in an authentication process unless that step provides at least one of the following: Level AAA. (https://www.w3.org/TR/WCAG22/#accessible-authentication-enhanced)

Instructions.$value: A cognitive function test (such as remembering a password or solving a puzzle) is not required for any step in an authentication process unless that step provides at least one of the following:

Case_1.$value: Alternative - Another authentication method that does not rely on a cognitive function test.
Case_1.$description: Alternative - Another authentication method that does not rely on a cognitive function test.

Case_2.$value: Mechanism - A mechanism is available to assist the user in completing the cognitive function test.
Case_2.$description: Mechanism - A mechanism is available to assist the user in completing the cognitive function test.
